content.text: In classical logic, a contradiction implies everything: from 'A and not-A,' any proposition follows. This is the **explosion principle** (ex contradictione quodlibet). Paraconsistent logics reject this, allowing contradictions without total collapse.

content.definition: The classical principle that from a contradiction, anything follows: (A ∧ ¬A) → B for any B. 'From falsehood, anything' — one contradiction destroys the entire system.

content.text: Why tolerate contradictions? Because real databases often contain inconsistencies, and we still want to reason with them. We don't want one error to make everything true.

content.title: Classical Explosion
content.note: This proof works for ANY B — one contradiction proves everything.

content.definition: A logic in which contradictions don't explode into proving everything. The inference from A ∧ ¬A to arbitrary B is blocked.

content.text: **Dialethism** goes further: some contradictions are actually true! The Liar Paradox ('This sentence is false') might be both true AND false. Paraconsistent logic provides tools for such views.

content.question: What does paraconsistent logic reject?
content.explanation: Paraconsistent logic rejects the explosion principle — the idea that from a contradiction, anything follows. This allows reasoning in systems that contain some inconsistencies.
